title: Episode 02 – Judith Schwartz – Author & Soil Expert
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
description: Episode 02 – Interview with Judith Schwartz on the Y on Earth Community Podcast – Stewardship & Sustainability Series.
full_transcript:
[9.5s - 16.5s]: Hi friends, welcome to another session of the Why on Earth community stewardship and

[16.5s - 17.9s]: sustainability series.

[18.7s - 26.4s]: And I'm so overjoyed to have this opportunity to have with us Judith Schwartz today and

[26.4s - 27.5s]: welcome Judy.

[28.1s - 28.9s]: Thank you.

[29.7s - 36.6s]: Judy Judith is the author of Cow Save the Planet as well as Water and Plain

[36.6s - 36.8s]: Site.

[36.8s - 40.7s]: I've actually got my copy right here of Water and Plain Site if you can see that.

[42.5s - 49.4s]: And Judy and I, we've been corresponding now for maybe something approaching two years

[50.1s - 55.4s]: and have connected I think primarily around soil related issues.

[55.4s - 61.9s]: And she is an incredible expert on these topics and it's such a joy.

[62.1s - 68.2s]: Judy, to have this opportunity to chat with you and to share a bit of your work with the

[68.2s - 69.4s]: Why on Earth community.

[69.4s - 70.8s]: So thank you.

[70.8s - 71.8s]: Oh, my pleasure.

[73.2s - 79.2s]: So I thought it might be fun just knowing that one of the things you talk about is this

[79.2s - 81.1s]: connection between soil and water.

[81.1s - 85.2s]: I thought it might be fun to hang behind me a couple of paintings.

[85.5s - 88.3s]: One is an homage to soil.

[88.6s - 89.7s]: Of course, that's on this side.

[90.2s - 92.1s]: And one is an homage to water.

[93.0s - 101.0s]: And so perhaps we could kick off by having you share with us what is that connection and

[101.0s - 104.1s]: why why on earth why on earth is that important?

[105.0s - 109.9s]: Yeah, so soil and water are intimately connected.

[110.4s - 117.4s]: And the way I often talk about it is that we can think about soil as our best water infrastructure.

[118.1s - 124.2s]: When we think about water infrastructure, we think about these big dams and channels

[124.2s - 132.2s]: and everything whisking water away from our cities where a lot of water causes storm

[132.8s - 135.3s]: surges and different problems.

[136.2s - 143.0s]: And so what happens is that we remove water from its intimate connection with the soil because

[144.0s - 146.9s]: water because soil when it's healthy holds water.

[147.1s - 154.7s]: I mean, one statistic that I often use and this is from the USDA is that one additional

[155.4s - 162.9s]: 1% increase of soil organic carbon because when you have carbon in the soil that's healthy

[162.9s - 169.2s]: in the soil, that's a lot of organic matter and that acts as a sponge, that represents an

[169.2s - 175.3s]: additional 25,000 gallons of water that can be held on the land.

[175.9s - 181.5s]: So there's a huge connection because if you have soil that doesn't have a lot of carbon

[181.5s - 189.0s]: if it's essentially dirt, well that soil can hold water and that's what we see all over.

[189.0s - 195.8s]: That's the backstory to floods and droughts and wildfires and all these other challenges

[195.8s - 199.3s]: that we have. Oh, including pollution in our waterways.

[199.6s - 203.3s]: Right. All right, I want to make sure I get this right.

[203.5s - 205.0s]: I'm going to make a note actually of this.

[205.0s - 213.7s]: So we're talking about in in soil a 1% increase of organic matter in soil equates to a 25,000

[213.7s - 218.5s]: gallon additional water absorption capacity in what area is that?

[218.6s - 219.3s]: For acre.

[219.8s - 220.2s]: For acre.

[220.6s - 222.5s]: Okay, that's tremendous.

[223.3s - 223.8s]: That's yeah.

[224.0s - 225.2s]: Yes, it is.

[225.4s - 226.6s]: I'm running it down.

[228.7s - 232.7s]: And what can people do?

[233.6s - 241.3s]: Of course, many of our friends who are farmers, folks who are managing large landscapes

[241.8s - 249.3s]: are doing incredible regenerative work with soil to build up that soil carbon content,

[249.3s - 251.0s]: that organic matter in the soil.

[251.8s - 260.5s]: What can regular folks do perhaps in our own homes, yards, neighborhoods to help build soil,

[261.2s - 267.4s]: carbon and help create a better water infrastructure if you will?

[268.1s - 274.2s]: Well, the first thing to do is to stop putting chemicals on your lawn.

[274.2s - 280.0s]: Now, this is something that I'm exploring in my community because you're, you know, because,

[280.9s - 285.7s]: you know, what when I look at green spaces, I don't know what the town is doing.

[285.9s - 293.6s]: You know, I learned that the town often uses herbicides to manage some of the green space.

[294.1s - 298.7s]: So, but stop, definitely stop doing that for many, many reasons.

[299.4s - 306.3s]: Okay, so we can take, well, let's take fertilizer because people often don't understand that.

[307.1s - 313.7s]: So, when you have synthetic nitrogen fertilizer, you're adding nitrogen to the soil.

[314.4s - 319.4s]: And, you know, nitrogen is important in the soil and they're just like we have a carbon cycle,

[319.6s - 322.7s]: we have a nutrient cycle, which is driven by nitrogen.

[323.7s - 328.0s]: So, there's all this barter that goes on in the ground.

[328.7s - 333.2s]: In the soil, you've got all these microorganisms doing all this stuff.

[334.1s - 337.5s]: And so, basically, you've got the, you've got the plant.

[338.1s - 345.4s]: And then the plant is creating carbon from sunlight and, and water and the process of photosynthesis.

[346.0s - 352.3s]: And sending carbon down into the soil and all these microorganisms are very excited about this carbon.

[352.4s - 356.5s]: And they're feeding on carbon and they're trading nutrients with the plant.

[356.5s - 359.2s]: And one of those nutrients is nitrogen.

[360.1s - 367.2s]: And when we add nitrogen to the soil, that messes up that whole barter system.

[367.6s - 373.3s]: So, that's, that's turning off the mechanism is telling the plant, oh, you've got this.

[373.6s - 377.9s]: You don't need to interact with all these other microorganisms.

[378.2s - 384.3s]: So, you don't get carbon flowing into the soil in the same way being taken up by microorganisms.

[384.3s - 391.3s]: So, yeah, so there's the, there's a really interesting scientist that talks a lot about the

[391.3s - 397.1s]: soil carbon sponge. He was just on a soil carbon sponge tour through North America.

[397.8s - 405.0s]: His name is Walter Yena. And I met up with him in Kansas. We were speaking in a few different

[405.0s - 413.9s]: things to events together. And he said, in this totally gloomy way, that for every,

[414.8s - 422.9s]: like every excess gram of nitrogen, fertile, of, you know, mainly nitrogen fertilizer.

[423.0s - 427.7s]: And we know that much of, because nitrogen fertilizer is relatively cheap,

[428.5s - 433.1s]: people put on much more than they need. And people, we don't really need it anyway.

[435.7s - 442.4s]: That, because there is nitrogen in the, in the landscape and there in the atmosphere,

[443.2s - 449.7s]: nitrogen, you know, there's a ton of nitrogen in the atmosphere. And there are microbes in the soil

[449.7s - 455.5s]: that can convert it to, to nitrogen that's able to be taken up by plants. But what he said is that,

[455.5s - 468.8s]: like every one gram of excess nitrogen flowing into the soil is, it represents 30 grams of carbon

[468.8s - 477.2s]: being volatized, meaning being put into the atmosphere where it oxidizes, it combines with oxygen.

[477.9s - 484.0s]: And there's then CO2. I mean, that just blew me away. And the, I asked him for an explanation,

[484.0s - 490.7s]: and it had to do with what the fungi and the soil are doing. But anyway, that's really important.

[491.0s - 499.7s]: We know that too much nitrogen actually caught, it causes a lot of nitrous oxide. But there's this

[499.7s - 508.8s]: carbon dynamic too. So it's such a powerful, I think, thing for us to understand about this

[509.5s - 514.9s]: incredible planet. And I like to use the word miraculous. That's the word that resonates for me

[514.9s - 522.3s]: when thinking about this amazing planet Earth that we live on. And nitrogen is so abundant, right?

[522.4s - 526.8s]: My understanding is what 70-some percent of the atmosphere. Yes.

[527.4s - 535.8s]: In my grandpa, I remember would often describe a snow, a wet snow in the spring as core man's fertilizer.

[536.7s - 543.5s]: And there's actually a something going on that's one of the ways in which atmospheric nitrogen is

[543.5s - 553.8s]: making its way into the soil. Of course, the incredible, complex activities of the soil microbiome,

[554.0s - 560.2s]: all of those little critters in the soil is a huge part of what's going on with nitrogen and

[560.2s - 566.1s]: with carbon, as you're saying. And it strikes me. I've got friends and family who think of gardening

[566.1s - 572.5s]: or farming in terms of needing to apply nitrogen. And if we're not doing that somehow,

[572.7s - 578.6s]: we're going to produce less food or perhaps have fewer flowers in our garden or whatever it might be.

[579.0s - 585.0s]: And I think there's a real opportunity here for people to understand that the miraculous

[585.0s - 592.2s]: mechanisms of this planet have already got us covered in this regard. And that much of what we've

[592.2s - 599.0s]: been doing over the last 100 years or so has actually been incredibly disruptive to those natural

[599.0s - 606.0s]: cycles. And of course, we know, looking at the history of this, that nitrogen is a central

[606.0s - 613.1s]: ingredient in the munitions we utilized in World War I and utilized in World War II. And my grandfather

[613.1s - 621.1s]: fought in that war against the fascists in Europe. And then we as a nation here in the United States

[621.1s - 628.9s]: made a decision to keep that nitrogen production at elevated levels and went into agricultural uses

[630.0s - 638.0s]: now in addition to munitions uses. And so it's a complex story. And it's one that we get to make

[638.0s - 646.8s]: choices about now in our own homes and yards and neighborhoods. My hope is that as people hear from you

[647.6s - 653.2s]: and some of the other experts out there in the world talking on this, it helps us decide, you know,

[653.4s - 657.9s]: what I don't need to buy that nitrogen fertilizer. What I'm going to do is start working with the

[658.5s - 665.9s]: soil microbiome and start collaborating and cooperating with this incredibly rich and complex

[666.5s - 674.0s]: system that is naturally there. Absolutely. When I was writing my last book, I was talking to

[674.8s - 682.0s]: another Australian scientist, Christine Jones, who has the website amazing carbon.com, which I find very

[682.0s - 689.1s]: memorable. So when she was pointing out and here I was sitting outside, I live in Southern Vermont,

[689.1s - 697.2s]: and she said, when plants are deprived of nitrogen, they turn yellow. And if you look out in a natural

[697.2s - 703.5s]: system, you see green plants without yellow. And there was, you know, just like, I think it was in

[703.5s - 711.1s]: June, just like, you know, my landscape is right now. And all I see is green. And so that means

[711.1s - 717.9s]: that those plants are getting nitrogen somehow. So that was really powerful. But this whole thing about

[717.9s - 726.0s]: what we think green space should look like just has us totally addicted to nitrogen fertilizer.

[726.8s - 737.0s]: And I was talking to a fellow who runs a, or I guess he sold it, but ran an organic lawn service.

[737.1s - 744.2s]: And he talks about how the notion that the types of grass that we're supposed to have in our lawns

[746.0s - 753.5s]: and the way that they're supposed to look sets up a condition that we are dependent on all of this

[754.0s - 761.8s]: whole, you know, this whole set of stuff that we need to buy. Because the verminigrass, I think

[761.8s - 769.1s]: that it's life cycle is such that by the middle of the summer, you're going to need a lot of help,

[769.1s - 774.5s]: it needs more water, it needs more nitrogen. And he was saying that even something as simple

[775.2s - 783.5s]: as adding clover to the mix, clover is in legume. So it fixes nice nitrogen at the root will

[783.5s - 791.0s]: benefit. But somehow we have this idea that clover is, clover is our weeps. Of course, red clover is

[791.0s - 800.7s]: our state flower, but still, yeah, it sets up this kind of ridiculous counterproductive dynamic.

[802.1s - 808.1s]: Absolutely. We have recently been spending a fair bit of time with the herbalist Brigitte

[808.1s - 815.1s]: Mars, dear friend, and who is educating so many people. And she talks a lot about the dandelions.

[815.1s - 821.7s]: And that we regard often dandelions as weeds, because somehow they don't look like what we imagine

[821.7s - 826.2s]: is the ideal landscape or something like this. And it turns out they are one of the most important

[826.2s - 833.5s]: food sources early in the spring for the pollinators, the bees and others. And as we're becoming good

[833.5s - 841.7s]: stewards of our places, I think that to connect some of these dots in our own homes, in our own

[841.7s - 848.4s]: neighborhoods, becomes extremely powerful. And we begin to see the positive cascading effects of

[848.4s - 854.5s]: taking good care of soil, taking good care of water, not poisoning any of this, and taking good

[854.5s - 861.1s]: care of these plants who have incredible purpose and virtue. And I forget who said it, but somebody

[861.7s - 867.7s]: is quoted as saying that weeds are what we call plants whose virtues we have not yet discovered.

[868.5s - 874.0s]: These plants have incredible roles and functions to play in these ecosystems. And by golly,

[874.0s - 876.7s]: we get to play with them and be good friends of theirs.

[877.3s - 883.8s]: Right. So the other flip in addition to not putting nitrogen fertilizer on is not putting on

[883.8s - 891.4s]: herbicides and pesticides, because there are, oh, there's always, you can call it collateral damage,

[891.8s - 897.4s]: but I mean, once you destroy one thing, you're destroying something else, and then you

[897.4s - 903.8s]: have that kind of cascading effect. Now, for, um, at keeping nitrogen going in the system,

[904.0s - 911.0s]: there's another way to do it. And that is what I'm experimenting with right now. And it's funny,

[911.2s - 920.1s]: you mentioned your backdrop. My backdrop here on my chair is a, is a sheep hide from a friend of mine

[920.1s - 927.0s]: here in Vermont that run Jesse McDougal, who has a farm, a regenerative farm called Studio Hill farm.

[927.4s - 933.0s]: And I recommend people looking that up because they are telling beautiful stories about their farm and

[933.0s - 938.8s]: how every year the biodiversity improves. I was just up there the other day and they're getting a lot

[938.8s - 945.0s]: of bubble links, which have been disappearing in this region or the numbers have been dwindled. But just,

[945.3s - 952.8s]: you know, just something magical appears. Just know you improve the land and there goes. But anyway,

[952.8s - 961.5s]: the experiment that I'm doing is having sheep on the landscape. And this is, this is an experiment.

[961.8s - 968.7s]: It's going to be for my next book. My next book is called Restoration Flashmob. So it's about

[968.7s - 975.9s]: restoring the earth. Okay. So it kind of articulates the ecosystem restoration, regenerative agriculture

[976.8s - 984.7s]: movement, which is growing. And there's going to be a narrative thread of restoring the land

[985.7s - 991.4s]: here on our property. We own 12 acres. And what's happening is I was beginning to feel like I was

[991.4s - 998.9s]: living in two worlds that here I'd go to someplace in Africa or in Mexico or in Canada where they're

[998.9s - 1003.8s]: restoring the land. And then I come back and I sit at my computer and you know, wait a second,

[1003.8s - 1010.5s]: there's something missing here. So I wanted to see just kind of, you know, ask some questions about

[1010.5s - 1017.5s]: our land. So it turns out there's a through our little network and the underground sheep

[1018.6s - 1025.6s]: community here that I found someone who really was just as happy to have fewer sheep during this

[1025.6s - 1035.3s]: summer season. And so enter six lovely sheep onto our land. And so we're still getting the handle,

[1035.3s - 1041.6s]: handle on the moving them, but it's really, really interesting. And I'm telling you, you will not

[1042.4s - 1051.2s]: look at Green space the same way again, because now I look at it and I see food for animals. So if

[1051.2s - 1058.3s]: you think about it, when we mow our lawns, that has huge number of impacts. You're compacting the

[1058.3s - 1066.1s]: soil, which means that you don't get the same air ration and water flow. Okay, with the lawn mower,

[1066.4s - 1081.2s]: of course, you're burning fossil fuels. You know, you're doing all these other things. And,

[1081.2s - 1091.0s]: eating all that, that excess green stuff, that's kept biologically alive. That's creating wool

[1091.0s - 1101.2s]: and meat and hives and love because they are beautiful and so sweet and they snuggle together.

[1102.1s - 1111.2s]: And they make me happy when I see them. So there you go. And why, I mean, why wouldn't we have them

[1111.2s - 1120.8s]: everywhere? Think of all the new work for shepherds or for people that maybe go around and bring

[1120.8s - 1129.4s]: their sheep to people's lawns. And I don't see a downside at all. So it's really quite extraordinary.

[1129.4s - 1135.5s]: I mean, I could know before I had the sheep on the land, I could know this intellectually. But when

[1135.5s - 1143.5s]: you actually see, when we move the sheep from one paddock where they've pretty much eaten down,

[1143.9s - 1149.4s]: you know, they've kind of, you know, gotten as low as we want the grass to grow, to go.

[1150.4s - 1155.6s]: And then bring them to a new paddock, you know, new fresh grass with all, you know,

[1155.6s - 1160.8s]: dandelions and all these wonderful wee-y things that, you know, whose names I don't even know.

[1161.9s - 1168.4s]: They are just so joyous. You know, I mean, they're so excited.

[1169.0s - 1176.2s]: What a delight. You know, okay, I got to really quickly take a pause and give a shout out to the

[1176.2s - 1182.7s]: Y on Earth community. And for folks who are tuning in to our podcast, I want to mention you can go to

[1182.7s - 1193.0s]: yon earth.org slash market and use the code podcast to get some special deals on our audio books and

[1193.0s - 1201.3s]: other great listening content that we've put together for you. And also, with the Y on Earth

[1201.3s - 1206.7s]: community, I am so excited. I actually, Judy, I don't think I recall you mentioning the name of

[1206.7s - 1212.3s]: the book you're working on restoration flashmob. And I'm so excited because with the Y on Earth

[1212.3s - 1221.5s]: community, one of our big initiatives now is working with probiotic, biodynamic soil activator

[1222.1s - 1230.0s]: in communities all over this continent, really, to help engage in relationship with place with

[1230.0s - 1237.8s]: soil and to help get those positive cascading effects going with that soil microbiology. And we're now

[1237.8s - 1245.6s]: we'll be doing some things in cities, the bourbon areas, rural areas. And part of the fun is we get to

[1246.3s - 1252.9s]: put on a little backpack after stirring this up in some water and literally walking through our

[1252.9s - 1259.0s]: neighborhood along the sidewalk or in the park. Imagine we get to sprinkle a little bit of this

[1259.0s - 1267.4s]: incredible goodness all over and really start to engage in a process of healing that is joy

[1267.4s - 1275.8s]: filled. And to be honest, quite a lot of fun. And not technically difficult to do. And so with

[1275.8s - 1282.3s]: the Y on Earth community, one of the things I'm so excited about is we can work with folks living

[1282.3s - 1287.1s]: in all kinds of different situations and settings. Now, some of my friends, perhaps in

[1287.1s - 1293.3s]: Midtown Manhattan aren't going to bring sheep into their situation. But we can still work with

[1293.3s - 1300.0s]: soil absolutely wherever we are. And it's just it's an incredible opportunity. We have really for

[1300.0s - 1308.9s]: all of us on the planet, I believe. Yeah, you just you just start looking at at land, just how much land

[1308.9s - 1316.9s]: isn't being used. And you know, the folly of us saying, well, you know, we don't have we don't

[1316.9s - 1324.5s]: have enough food to support everybody. Well, there's food happening in my yard. And you know, we can

[1325.5s - 1333.9s]: you know, row tree trees and the friend of mine is just starting to have a perennial food garden.

[1334.0s - 1340.7s]: I mean, there's just so many opportunities. Yes, yes, we really we get to work with the animals,

[1340.7s - 1345.5s]: with the soil microbiome, with the plants and the trees. And in a sense,

[1346.4s - 1352.3s]: collaborate with those forces and energies that want to have places

[1353.0s - 1358.1s]: feel like what we would imagine the garden of Eden to feel like. We get to do this in cities.

[1358.5s - 1365.6s]: We get to do this in rural landscapes. There's so much abundance and so much that wants to happen.

[1365.6s - 1373.4s]: If we can just, you know, stop the practices that are inhibiting this and interrupting this and

[1373.4s - 1379.2s]: interfering with this and then start to work with these forces collaboratively,

[1379.3s - 1383.3s]: cooperatively, gosh, and it turns out like you're saying it makes you happy. It turns out it's going

[1383.3s - 1392.7s]: to enhance our own quality of life in the process. Of course, I mean, it is sort of crazy that we that

[1393.3s - 1403.5s]: the way that we think our landscape should look are this kind of static green kind of shag carpet.

[1405.7s - 1412.7s]: Yeah, so yeah, there's so much we can do. And yet the way that our systems are, I mean,

[1412.8s - 1418.8s]: it makes me nuts down at the bottom of I live on a mountain mountain slope and down at the bottom

[1418.8s - 1428.4s]: of the mountain road. People are own a dairy farmer owns the land and they're putting GMO corn

[1429.1s - 1438.5s]: on the ground to feed the cow. I mean, this is insane. Whereas all that land, they could be managing

[1438.5s - 1447.7s]: that land with the animals, of course, or with sheep or with, I mean, those cows shouldn't even be

[1447.7s - 1458.8s]: eating GMO corn or corn at all. That matter. That ties up all that land. Yeah, we know and share

[1458.8s - 1469.7s]: with folks that one of the ways we're causing distress and disease in our world is by overloading cows

[1469.7s - 1475.4s]: with corn and creating a condition called acidosis. It's actually acidifying their bodies. And it's

[1475.6s - 1481.0s]: one of the reasons conventional cattle and dairy industry folks are having to use all of these

[1481.0s - 1486.9s]: antibiotics and so forth. The immune systems of those core creatures are actually in the process of

[1486.9s - 1493.5s]: collapsing. And there's almost in that model this race to the slaughterhouse where you're trying to

[1493.5s - 1500.9s]: get as much weight on the hoof. It's called of that animal to sell into the market. Before that core

[1500.9s - 1509.5s]: animal actually collapses from being so overwhelmed by disease. And feeding corn to these animals that

[1509.5s - 1515.5s]: are beautifully designed to eat grasses. With their many stomachs, they have this incredible

[1516.5s - 1522.3s]: microbiome of their own. I heard recently mentioned up at a biodynamic farm. We love visiting

[1522.9s - 1528.1s]: that the nutrient input to output with cattle working with grasses. Something like

[1529.2s - 1536.8s]: a one for every one unit in. We get three units out in that microbial rich manure that gets

[1536.8s - 1545.7s]: back into that landscape and back with that soil. And so my goodness, this whole setup has been

[1546.5s - 1553.8s]: created by incredible intelligence, nature's intelligence. And if we might cultivate a bit of

[1554.1s - 1561.4s]: humility and come to understand really how perfect so much of these systems have been created

[1561.4s - 1569.3s]: naturally and work to collaborate instead of effectively waging war against soil and causing

[1569.3s - 1578.4s]: incredibly sad scenarios for animals and for people. Right. Right. To celebrate the biodiversity,

[1579.0s - 1587.5s]: as opposed to trying to, you know, collaborate with by thinking of weeds as undesirable plants.

[1588.2s - 1594.0s]: As opposed to, as you said, we don't know the benefits of plants that we don't know the benefits

[1594.0s - 1602.7s]: of yet. But also there is source of information because depending on the condition of the soil,

[1603.3s - 1611.9s]: different plants will show up to try to fix the soil. So once we start to understand that, we can say,

[1612.1s - 1617.5s]: oh, if this particular plant is showing up now, well, that's telling me that the soil is to

[1617.5s - 1623.2s]: acid, the soil is to compact it, you know, for compaction, we have all those taproot

[1624.6s - 1630.5s]: plants that show up. And that's what they're trying to do. They're trying to break up the compaction.

[1631.5s - 1637.9s]: I love this. So it's as if if we if we've got a species of plant moving into our place that we

[1637.9s - 1645.8s]: don't necessarily want to understand why we might appreciate it's being there. In a sense,

[1646.1s - 1652.7s]: we ought to come to appreciate it's actually giving us a message, right. It's telling us a signal

[1652.7s - 1660.5s]: about what's going on in this place. It's not actually the problem that there is a problem. It's

[1660.5s - 1667.4s]: exactly. So I guess one thing that we all need to do and everybody, you know, we all get into habits

[1667.4s - 1674.4s]: of thought and and just going along with the way that things have always been done is to is to pause

[1674.4s - 1685.8s]: and say, hmm, maybe I don't need to put this on our property or maybe in our children's school yard,

[1685.8s - 1692.8s]: we parents can get together and try to do something different rather than have life estate on to make it

[1702.3s - 1709.4s]: I don't like this weed. Wait a second. Okay. No, I mean, dandelions are beautiful. They're beautiful.

[1729.3s - 1737.1s]: in here quite soon? Sounds good to me. Awesome, Judy. Well, I want to be sure to mention that for

segments.text: Hi friends, welcome to another session of the Why on Earth community stewardship and
sustainability series.
And I'm so overjoyed to have this opportunity to have with us Judith Schwartz today and
welcome Judy.
Thank you.
Judy Judith is the author of Cow Save the Planet as well as Water and Plain
Site.
I've actually got my copy right here of Water and Plain Site if you can see that.
And Judy and I, we've been corresponding now for maybe something approaching two years
and have connected I think primarily around soil related issues.
And she is an incredible expert on these topics and it's such a joy.
Judy, to have this opportunity to chat with you and to share a bit of your work with the
Why on Earth community.
So thank you.
Oh, my pleasure.
So I thought it might be fun just knowing that one of the things you talk about is this
connection between soil and water.
I thought it might be fun to hang behind me a couple of paintings.
One is an homage to soil.
Of course, that's on this side.
And one is an homage to water.
And so perhaps we could kick off by having you share with us what is that connection and
why why on earth why on earth is that important?
Yeah, so soil and water are intimately connected.
And the way I often talk about it is that we can think about soil as our best water infrastructure.
When we think about water infrastructure, we think about these big dams and channels
and everything whisking water away from our cities where a lot of water causes storm
surges and different problems.
And so what happens is that we remove water from its intimate connection with the soil because
water because soil when it's healthy holds water.
I mean, one statistic that I often use and this is from the USDA is that one additional
1% increase of soil organic carbon because when you have carbon in the soil that's healthy
in the soil, that's a lot of organic matter and that acts as a sponge, that represents an
additional 25,000 gallons of water that can be held on the land.
So there's a huge connection because if you have soil that doesn't have a lot of carbon
if it's essentially dirt, well that soil can hold water and that's what we see all over.
That's the backstory to floods and droughts and wildfires and all these other challenges
that we have. Oh, including pollution in our waterways.
Right. All right, I want to make sure I get this right.
I'm going to make a note actually of this.
So we're talking about in in soil a 1% increase of organic matter in soil equates to a 25,000
gallon additional water absorption capacity in what area is that?
For acre.
For acre.
Okay, that's tremendous.
That's yeah.
Yes, it is.
I'm running it down.
And what can people do?
Of course, many of our friends who are farmers, folks who are managing large landscapes
are doing incredible regenerative work with soil to build up that soil carbon content,
that organic matter in the soil.
What can regular folks do perhaps in our own homes, yards, neighborhoods to help build soil,
carbon and help create a better water infrastructure if you will?
Well, the first thing to do is to stop putting chemicals on your lawn.
Now, this is something that I'm exploring in my community because you're, you know, because,
you know, what when I look at green spaces, I don't know what the town is doing.
You know, I learned that the town often uses herbicides to manage some of the green space.
So, but stop, definitely stop doing that for many, many reasons.
Okay, so we can take, well, let's take fertilizer because people often don't understand that.
So, when you have synthetic nitrogen fertilizer, you're adding nitrogen to the soil.
And, you know, nitrogen is important in the soil and they're just like we have a carbon cycle,
we have a nutrient cycle, which is driven by nitrogen.
So, there's all this barter that goes on in the ground.
In the soil, you've got all these microorganisms doing all this stuff.
And so, basically, you've got the, you've got the plant.
And then the plant is creating carbon from sunlight and, and water and the process of photosynthesis.
And sending carbon down into the soil and all these microorganisms are very excited about this carbon.
And they're feeding on carbon and they're trading nutrients with the plant.
And one of those nutrients is nitrogen.
And when we add nitrogen to the soil, that messes up that whole barter system.
So, that's, that's turning off the mechanism is telling the plant, oh, you've got this.
You don't need to interact with all these other microorganisms.
So, you don't get carbon flowing into the soil in the same way being taken up by microorganisms.
So, yeah, so there's the, there's a really interesting scientist that talks a lot about the
soil carbon sponge. He was just on a soil carbon sponge tour through North America.
His name is Walter Yena. And I met up with him in Kansas. We were speaking in a few different
things to events together. And he said, in this totally gloomy way, that for every,
like every excess gram of nitrogen, fertile, of, you know, mainly nitrogen fertilizer.
And we know that much of, because nitrogen fertilizer is relatively cheap,
people put on much more than they need. And people, we don't really need it anyway.
That, because there is nitrogen in the, in the landscape and there in the atmosphere,
nitrogen, you know, there's a ton of nitrogen in the atmosphere. And there are microbes in the soil
that can convert it to, to nitrogen that's able to be taken up by plants. But what he said is that,
like every one gram of excess nitrogen flowing into the soil is, it represents 30 grams of carbon
being volatized, meaning being put into the atmosphere where it oxidizes, it combines with oxygen.
And there's then CO2. I mean, that just blew me away. And the, I asked him for an explanation,
and it had to do with what the fungi and the soil are doing. But anyway, that's really important.
We know that too much nitrogen actually caught, it causes a lot of nitrous oxide. But there's this
carbon dynamic too. So it's such a powerful, I think, thing for us to understand about this
incredible planet. And I like to use the word miraculous. That's the word that resonates for me
when thinking about this amazing planet Earth that we live on. And nitrogen is so abundant, right?
My understanding is what 70-some percent of the atmosphere. Yes.
In my grandpa, I remember would often describe a snow, a wet snow in the spring as core man's fertilizer.
And there's actually a something going on that's one of the ways in which atmospheric nitrogen is
making its way into the soil. Of course, the incredible, complex activities of the soil microbiome,
all of those little critters in the soil is a huge part of what's going on with nitrogen and
with carbon, as you're saying. And it strikes me. I've got friends and family who think of gardening
or farming in terms of needing to apply nitrogen. And if we're not doing that somehow,
we're going to produce less food or perhaps have fewer flowers in our garden or whatever it might be.
And I think there's a real opportunity here for people to understand that the miraculous
mechanisms of this planet have already got us covered in this regard. And that much of what we've
been doing over the last 100 years or so has actually been incredibly disruptive to those natural
cycles. And of course, we know, looking at the history of this, that nitrogen is a central
ingredient in the munitions we utilized in World War I and utilized in World War II. And my grandfather
fought in that war against the fascists in Europe. And then we as a nation here in the United States
made a decision to keep that nitrogen production at elevated levels and went into agricultural uses
now in addition to munitions uses. And so it's a complex story. And it's one that we get to make
choices about now in our own homes and yards and neighborhoods. My hope is that as people hear from you
and some of the other experts out there in the world talking on this, it helps us decide, you know,
what I don't need to buy that nitrogen fertilizer. What I'm going to do is start working with the
soil microbiome and start collaborating and cooperating with this incredibly rich and complex
system that is naturally there. Absolutely. When I was writing my last book, I was talking to
another Australian scientist, Christine Jones, who has the website amazing carbon.com, which I find very
memorable. So when she was pointing out and here I was sitting outside, I live in Southern Vermont,
and she said, when plants are deprived of nitrogen, they turn yellow. And if you look out in a natural
system, you see green plants without yellow. And there was, you know, just like, I think it was in
June, just like, you know, my landscape is right now. And all I see is green. And so that means
that those plants are getting nitrogen somehow. So that was really powerful. But this whole thing about
what we think green space should look like just has us totally addicted to nitrogen fertilizer.
And I was talking to a fellow who runs a, or I guess he sold it, but ran an organic lawn service.
And he talks about how the notion that the types of grass that we're supposed to have in our lawns
and the way that they're supposed to look sets up a condition that we are dependent on all of this
whole, you know, this whole set of stuff that we need to buy. Because the verminigrass, I think
that it's life cycle is such that by the middle of the summer, you're going to need a lot of help,
it needs more water, it needs more nitrogen. And he was saying that even something as simple
as adding clover to the mix, clover is in legume. So it fixes nice nitrogen at the root will
benefit. But somehow we have this idea that clover is, clover is our weeps. Of course, red clover is
our state flower, but still, yeah, it sets up this kind of ridiculous counterproductive dynamic.
Absolutely. We have recently been spending a fair bit of time with the herbalist Brigitte
Mars, dear friend, and who is educating so many people. And she talks a lot about the dandelions.
And that we regard often dandelions as weeds, because somehow they don't look like what we imagine
is the ideal landscape or something like this. And it turns out they are one of the most important
food sources early in the spring for the pollinators, the bees and others. And as we're becoming good
stewards of our places, I think that to connect some of these dots in our own homes, in our own
neighborhoods, becomes extremely powerful. And we begin to see the positive cascading effects of
taking good care of soil, taking good care of water, not poisoning any of this, and taking good
care of these plants who have incredible purpose and virtue. And I forget who said it, but somebody
is quoted as saying that weeds are what we call plants whose virtues we have not yet discovered.
These plants have incredible roles and functions to play in these ecosystems. And by golly,
we get to play with them and be good friends of theirs.
Right. So the other flip in addition to not putting nitrogen fertilizer on is not putting on
herbicides and pesticides, because there are, oh, there's always, you can call it collateral damage,
but I mean, once you destroy one thing, you're destroying something else, and then you
have that kind of cascading effect. Now, for, um, at keeping nitrogen going in the system,
there's another way to do it. And that is what I'm experimenting with right now. And it's funny,
you mentioned your backdrop. My backdrop here on my chair is a, is a sheep hide from a friend of mine
here in Vermont that run Jesse McDougal, who has a farm, a regenerative farm called Studio Hill farm.
And I recommend people looking that up because they are telling beautiful stories about their farm and
how every year the biodiversity improves. I was just up there the other day and they're getting a lot
of bubble links, which have been disappearing in this region or the numbers have been dwindled. But just,
you know, just something magical appears. Just know you improve the land and there goes. But anyway,
the experiment that I'm doing is having sheep on the landscape. And this is, this is an experiment.
It's going to be for my next book. My next book is called Restoration Flashmob. So it's about
restoring the earth. Okay. So it kind of articulates the ecosystem restoration, regenerative agriculture
movement, which is growing. And there's going to be a narrative thread of restoring the land
here on our property. We own 12 acres. And what's happening is I was beginning to feel like I was
living in two worlds that here I'd go to someplace in Africa or in Mexico or in Canada where they're
restoring the land. And then I come back and I sit at my computer and you know, wait a second,
there's something missing here. So I wanted to see just kind of, you know, ask some questions about
our land. So it turns out there's a through our little network and the underground sheep
community here that I found someone who really was just as happy to have fewer sheep during this
summer season. And so enter six lovely sheep onto our land. And so we're still getting the handle,
handle on the moving them, but it's really, really interesting. And I'm telling you, you will not
look at Green space the same way again, because now I look at it and I see food for animals. So if
you think about it, when we mow our lawns, that has huge number of impacts. You're compacting the
soil, which means that you don't get the same air ration and water flow. Okay, with the lawn mower,
of course, you're burning fossil fuels. You know, you're doing all these other things. And,
eating all that, that excess green stuff, that's kept biologically alive. That's creating wool
and meat and hives and love because they are beautiful and so sweet and they snuggle together.
And they make me happy when I see them. So there you go. And why, I mean, why wouldn't we have them
everywhere? Think of all the new work for shepherds or for people that maybe go around and bring
their sheep to people's lawns. And I don't see a downside at all. So it's really quite extraordinary.
I mean, I could know before I had the sheep on the land, I could know this intellectually. But when
you actually see, when we move the sheep from one paddock where they've pretty much eaten down,
you know, they've kind of, you know, gotten as low as we want the grass to grow, to go.
And then bring them to a new paddock, you know, new fresh grass with all, you know,
dandelions and all these wonderful wee-y things that, you know, whose names I don't even know.
They are just so joyous. You know, I mean, they're so excited.
What a delight. You know, okay, I got to really quickly take a pause and give a shout out to the
Y on Earth community. And for folks who are tuning in to our podcast, I want to mention you can go to
yon earth.org slash market and use the code podcast to get some special deals on our audio books and
other great listening content that we've put together for you. And also, with the Y on Earth
community, I am so excited. I actually, Judy, I don't think I recall you mentioning the name of
the book you're working on restoration flashmob. And I'm so excited because with the Y on Earth
community, one of our big initiatives now is working with probiotic, biodynamic soil activator
in communities all over this continent, really, to help engage in relationship with place with
soil and to help get those positive cascading effects going with that soil microbiology. And we're now
we'll be doing some things in cities, the bourbon areas, rural areas. And part of the fun is we get to
put on a little backpack after stirring this up in some water and literally walking through our
neighborhood along the sidewalk or in the park. Imagine we get to sprinkle a little bit of this
incredible goodness all over and really start to engage in a process of healing that is joy
filled. And to be honest, quite a lot of fun. And not technically difficult to do. And so with
the Y on Earth community, one of the things I'm so excited about is we can work with folks living
in all kinds of different situations and settings. Now, some of my friends, perhaps in
Midtown Manhattan aren't going to bring sheep into their situation. But we can still work with
soil absolutely wherever we are. And it's just it's an incredible opportunity. We have really for
all of us on the planet, I believe. Yeah, you just you just start looking at at land, just how much land
isn't being used. And you know, the folly of us saying, well, you know, we don't have we don't
have enough food to support everybody. Well, there's food happening in my yard. And you know, we can
you know, row tree trees and the friend of mine is just starting to have a perennial food garden.
I mean, there's just so many opportunities. Yes, yes, we really we get to work with the animals,
with the soil microbiome, with the plants and the trees. And in a sense,
collaborate with those forces and energies that want to have places
feel like what we would imagine the garden of Eden to feel like. We get to do this in cities.
We get to do this in rural landscapes. There's so much abundance and so much that wants to happen.
If we can just, you know, stop the practices that are inhibiting this and interrupting this and
interfering with this and then start to work with these forces collaboratively,
cooperatively, gosh, and it turns out like you're saying it makes you happy. It turns out it's going
to enhance our own quality of life in the process. Of course, I mean, it is sort of crazy that we that
the way that we think our landscape should look are this kind of static green kind of shag carpet.
Yeah, so yeah, there's so much we can do. And yet the way that our systems are, I mean,
it makes me nuts down at the bottom of I live on a mountain mountain slope and down at the bottom
of the mountain road. People are own a dairy farmer owns the land and they're putting GMO corn
on the ground to feed the cow. I mean, this is insane. Whereas all that land, they could be managing
that land with the animals, of course, or with sheep or with, I mean, those cows shouldn't even be
eating GMO corn or corn at all. That matter. That ties up all that land. Yeah, we know and share
with folks that one of the ways we're causing distress and disease in our world is by overloading cows
with corn and creating a condition called acidosis. It's actually acidifying their bodies. And it's
one of the reasons conventional cattle and dairy industry folks are having to use all of these
antibiotics and so forth. The immune systems of those core creatures are actually in the process of
collapsing. And there's almost in that model this race to the slaughterhouse where you're trying to
get as much weight on the hoof. It's called of that animal to sell into the market. Before that core
animal actually collapses from being so overwhelmed by disease. And feeding corn to these animals that
are beautifully designed to eat grasses. With their many stomachs, they have this incredible
microbiome of their own. I heard recently mentioned up at a biodynamic farm. We love visiting
that the nutrient input to output with cattle working with grasses. Something like
a one for every one unit in. We get three units out in that microbial rich manure that gets
back into that landscape and back with that soil. And so my goodness, this whole setup has been
created by incredible intelligence, nature's intelligence. And if we might cultivate a bit of
humility and come to understand really how perfect so much of these systems have been created
naturally and work to collaborate instead of effectively waging war against soil and causing
incredibly sad scenarios for animals and for people. Right. Right. To celebrate the biodiversity,
as opposed to trying to, you know, collaborate with by thinking of weeds as undesirable plants.
As opposed to, as you said, we don't know the benefits of plants that we don't know the benefits
of yet. But also there is source of information because depending on the condition of the soil,
different plants will show up to try to fix the soil. So once we start to understand that, we can say,
oh, if this particular plant is showing up now, well, that's telling me that the soil is to
acid, the soil is to compact it, you know, for compaction, we have all those taproot
plants that show up. And that's what they're trying to do. They're trying to break up the compaction.
I love this. So it's as if if we if we've got a species of plant moving into our place that we
don't necessarily want to understand why we might appreciate it's being there. In a sense,
we ought to come to appreciate it's actually giving us a message, right. It's telling us a signal
about what's going on in this place. It's not actually the problem that there is a problem. It's
exactly. So I guess one thing that we all need to do and everybody, you know, we all get into habits
of thought and and just going along with the way that things have always been done is to is to pause
and say, hmm, maybe I don't need to put this on our property or maybe in our children's school yard,
we parents can get together and try to do something different rather than have life estate on to make it
a, you know, a smoother, more uniform play area. And also, yeah, you know, when you say, oh no,
I don't like this weed. Wait a second. Okay. No, I mean, dandelions are beautiful. They're beautiful.
They really are. Well, what if our schools all over become increasingly these hubs where soil
regeneration is occurring and soil amendments and really soil and land medicines are being created
that can be broadcast into those surrounding communities? What if that's the world we get to be
in here quite soon? Sounds good to me. Awesome, Judy. Well, I want to be sure to mention that for
folks who want to see more about your books, cowsave the planet, water and plain sight, forthcoming

who might just be listening in? Okay. Judith, J U D I T H then D, shorts, S C H W A R T Z.
And then just my name dot com. That's so beautiful. Well, Judy, I am just thrilled to have this
opportunity to chat with you today and also really perhaps as importantly to be able to share
some of your knowledge and wisdom with others who were connected to and sharing this with.
So thanks for taking time out of your busy day to be with us. Okay, my pleasure. I'll be checking
on the on the sheep pretty soon. And we'll see what they all they're fertilizing and moving around
and eating the plants does for the land. I hope we get to see some pictures and videos here
with this as well. Yes, I'm sure. Beautiful. Well, thank you, Judy. Okay, thank you.
